tinguished members ot Congress we're among her
auditors. After finishing her sermon she sang
alone a long hymn; her voice was much admired
BY the best Judges The softest note of filed the
room.- She is woman Of delicate form and an ex-
pressive face. She is now past thirty five years of
age, and retains much Of the good looks Of her
youth. remember her, when 10 the blooming
charms of seventeen. she moved down the dance
wiM fairy step and laughing eyes" but little then
did anticipate the day when she would draw alter
her crowds Of hearers as preacher. think she
will do much good, for there is less fanacism and
more good IN her discourse than in those
sermons Of Whitfield which have been printed in
this country. The objections which have been
made to female preachers have heen nearly insur-
mouniable in this country, except among the
Friends: but Miss Livermore seems to unite the
Quaker and the Methodist and CONDUCTS e'sel! in
such manner as to please both seets. You may
smile to find me an advocate OF female preaching;
bu. can see no reason to exclude them from bear
ing the tidngs OF the Gospel which is peculiarly
engrs'ted on The best affections Of the heart And
who understands the heart better than enlighten
ed woman?

lie came unto his oma and his own received h


not--S,. John. chap. I, g
He came not in his peoples day,


or miracle and might,
When awe strack nations owned their sway
Aud conquest crowned each fsh';--
When Natutc's self with wondet saw
Her sneisnt power, her boastfnl law,


10 feeble man give way--
The clements Of earth and heaven
For Israel stayed--for Judah riven.
Pillar and cloud Jehovah gave,


HIGH emb.ems oi his grace;
Anu clsve the rock, and smote The wave,


Moved mountains from their place;
But luden,en, was with mercy blent-
Il, thunder was the promise sent


Fierce lightning vred his face
The les!ou. God-the burning law
Were all the chosen people saw.
Behold them pilgrim tribes no more


The promised land their own;
Aud blessings lheirs OF sea and shore,


To Other realms unknown;
From age 10 aye a favored line
Oi mighty kings and seers divine,


A temple and a throne;
Nj then. bu, ~ their hour Of shame,
Wo, want and weakness--then 4" he came."
NJ, in the earthquake. rending force,


No, IN the blasting fire,
Not in the strong winds rushing course,


Cams He, their souls desire
Forerunnrrs Of his coming these,
Proclaimins over earth and seas,


As (;od his might and ire:
he sill small voicr--the lowering dove,
Proved him Messsh-spoke him " Love-"
OF lite The way, of light the spring,


Eternal undef-d;
Redceme,. Prophet, Priest and king
Yet came he as child
And Zion's favored eye grown dim,
Knew not her proa ised Lord in him.


Tn. lowiy and the mild;
She saw The manger and the tree,
And scoth hlu cried" Can this be He!o

From thp Imutet.
MESSIAHS S ADVENT.

Washington, Jan 8, 1897.


Among the wonders of this place is The appear
ance OF female preacher. Miss Harriet Livermc,c
from Massac achusetts She has been we'll educated,
and is of highly respectable family. After having
preached in Georgetown and in some of he church.
es IN this city. she, by the assistance Of the Penn.
sylvapIa deleg ,tion, obtained from Mr.. Speaker
Taylor the liberty to "give her testimony" she
calls her sermon, in Congress Hall. The novelty
attracted all the taste and fashion Of the city and
the room was filled and crowded At / O'Clock on
Sunday last she entered the Hall took the Speakers
chair, sang hymn. assisted by few of her friends,
prayed, and began her discourse. The text was
from Cd Sam. chap. xiii. and A." He that
ruIcth men. must be just, ruling in the fear OF
God. And he shall be as the lighi Of The morning
when the sun rseth, even morning without clouds !:
as the tender grass .pringine out of the earth by
clear shining after rain" Her exposition of this
beautiful text was not only bold, bu, felicilous and
eloquent. Her voice wa. clear her annuncation so
distinct as to be heard by all on the Hoor OF the
house. She drew fair and lovely character Of the
just ruler, and dwe long upon the good such an ons
may do in this as we'll as in other countries. The
sermon was more than an hour in length, and all
we're quiet and attentive. The President was there,
and at time, sat upon the steps which led to her
pulpit, the crowd being so great that for while It
was the most convenient place he could End. The
Secretary of War, and some Of the most dis.

FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.
Washinpton, Jan. s, lSo

Many recipes have been given to the public for
curing beef; most important item in he depart
ment oil domestic economy-we recommend the
following With great confidence, for TWO reasons -
First because we have been favored with it by a
lady who cannot be cxeeed lor good taste and good
management; and secondly because we have dined
on beet picked By this process. which was super
excellent. Nm. Farmer.


Recipe for curing Bert.


Prepare your brine in the middle OF October,
after the following msnner:-Cet thirty gallon
cask, take out one head, drive in the hung and put
some pitch on it TO prevent lesking see that the
cssk is quite tight and clean Put into il one pound
OF salt petre powdered, fifteen quarts Of salt, and
fifteen gallons OF cold water, stir it frequently until
dissolved, throw over the cssk thick cloth to keep
out the dust look al it Of aud TAXI off the
fifteen gallons oil cold water will exactly hold, in
solution. fifteen quarts oil good. clean Liverpool
SALT and pound Of salt pelre this brine will
be strong enough TO bear up an egg This hrino
will cure all the beef which private family
use in the OF the winter, and eqoies nothing
TO be done to it, t occasionally skimniing
he droas tina; rises; II must be kept In COOL dry
place.


For sailing your beef-get mclassss hogshead
and saw it in t@o. that The beef may have space to
lie on bore some holes IN the bottom Of the tubs,
and raise them side about inch, that the
bloody brine msy run off. Rub each piece Of your
beef very well with good Liverpool salt vast deal
depends upon rubbing the ssh into eyesy part i, is
unnecessary to put salt petre on il sprinkle good
deal Of salt on the bottom of the tub. When the
beef Is well sailed, lay it in the tub and be sure
you put the heshy side downward; put grea, deal
o. sal: ON your nsef alter it is packed in ina tub.
this protects il from animals You must lc, the
oeef lie in salt ten days. then take it out, brash Of
the sal, aud wipe i. with damp cloth put j, in the
ine with . bit oi board and weight to keep it
under. In about ten days it will uok red and be
Fl for The best time 10 sah beef is in the
latter end OF October if the weather be cool ard
f., m that time have it 10 succession. When your
beet is taken cu ol the tub, stir the salt about ia
dfv that il rsy he ready for the next p,eCes.--
Tongues are cured in &c same manner.

Among the later the esteemed Lady who is the autho

Washington, 9th Jan, 1927.


My BELOVED CHILD:--l Witnessed scene
yesterday novel and impressive, that l cannot
torbear attempting description Of it. say at
! tempting. for the sensibies were more strongly
affected han the senses, consequently Just dein
cation is very difficult. IL had been rumored ior

see, auci all the professions of veDeration for
sex, made by mankind, when tested by their acts
they say "Wha, good thing can come out of Naz-
sreth 70


Thanks to the Christian Pastors Of Georgetown
they invited h~r to their Churches, from whence
the tame OF her eloquence spread through the City
cur osity esaed over iberal prejudice, and
she was invited to preach al the Capitol. We at
tended at an early hour, and found the hall, lobby
and gallery, completely filled tina, it was almost
impossible to get admission: And | am told the



When looked ,ound and the numerous
audience, greater Than | had ever on any for
mer occasion, tiembled for the yet unseen female
VIII" was TO address them At length she appeared
attic nded by friend Her figure is good, her height
somewhat above mediutrity her lace pale, perhaps
some would say PLAIN but peasi' e, and inuc alive
% great serenity and goodness They were ho'h
dressed il a style simple and neat you would
have taken them Qu.kers. She ascended the

her. She commenced in The usual manner, by
=, aver and singing. She then read the ll2th psal
IN voice some shat huf,ieG AID trrmunus, and

o the Sd and all oi ;he 4 b VERSES" He that rul
.ih over rnrn must Just. ruling in the fear OF

aheo the sun ristth even morning without clouds,
as t'e tende' grass sprnging out OF the earth BY
eirs, shining after rain


The President, and many members Of Con
sress weie es,n,. F,om her text you will read
IL, pc cei,e her address ended principally 70,
| the inlers oi the lation. Bot she embraced the
'hr ~h"lc multitude 1.-The iulers Of schools-the ru
iefs al 'amhes: and, as individuals, the rulers o
inf passirns.


Her language was correct, persuasive, and Iudg

sympathy OF the audience. extremely eloquent
| Many weps even 10 sohbing e. FIRST yielded tc





| to he melting mood, ]. who thoushl my heart was
scared by sfnic,ion aud my eyes dried BY weeping
found that hestl r~Ienling, aud those eyes dssolvine
in tricklng ihsw


| Judging, as said. by my owo ferIngs, and have
no other test. | should say she is The most eloquent
p,eache' have listened to since the days Of Mr.
| WaddeH.


| But no language car do justice 10 the psthns OF
her singing For when she closed by singing
hymn, that might with pop'iely he termed pray
er, in which she asks the divine perlectons of eat h
sacred character recorded in Scripture. her vnice
wa. so melodious, aud her face beamed with such
heavenly goodness, as to resemble rau.hgu, alton
and you compelled to accord tnem ali TO her
| could have listened from morn ill noon and rrn
noon till dewy eve Of Summers day 1t ssvourec
more OF inspiration Than any thing ever witnessed
and to enoy the frame OF mind which think she
does. would ,elinqush the world. Call this rhsp

A Real K,ntucLian.-A Kentuokian. we believe
of that class tamlisrly called a fog .Nerchant.
rode up to public house in the wes!. where's num-
he, OF gentlemen were seated in he piazza. Ahee
low bow to the company, h inquired It any pres
ent could infotm him what good tor ourn. A
young Physician (,hers being several present) step.
ned forward, and with much comp'slsance gave
him learned lecture on Burns, the mode ci treat
ment, &c. &c &c for which he was thanked politely
by the Ken'ut khan who informed him. that hi, pse-
scrpton would not answer hi, present complaint.
.. h,s saddle blanket had been very badly burnt the
nigh, previously. On hearing this the Physician
became exaspera,ed and told him il he would aligh,
he would give him Aogsiog. The Kentuckaa
-gain bowed and said that he would moi ahght Tor
TWO 1oggings let alone one, and rode off with muc.i
gravity and sell satisfaction.

tinguished members ot Congress we're among her

alone a long hymn; her voice was much admired
BY the best Judges The softest note of filed the
room.- She is woman Of delicate form and an ex-
pressive face. She is now past thirty five years of
age, and retains much Of the good looks Of her
youth. remember her, when 10 the blooming
charms of seventeen. she moved down the dance
wiM fairy step and laughing eyes" but little then
did anticipate the day when she would draw alter
her crowds Of hearers as preacher. think she
will do much good, for there is less fanacism and
more good IN her discourse than in those
sermons Of Whitfield which have been printed in
this country. The objections which have been
made to female preachers have heen nearly insur-
mouniable in this country, except among the
Friends: but Miss Livermore seems to unite the
Quaker and the Methodist and CONDUCTS e'sel! in
such manner as to please both seets. You may
smile to find me an advocate OF female preaching;
bu. can see no reason to exclude them from bear
ing the tidngs OF the Gospel which is peculiarly
engrs'ted on The best affections Of the heart And
who understands the heart better than enlighten
ed woman?

FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.
full articles.article:
Washington, Jan 8, 1897.


Among the wonders of this place is The appear
ance OF female preacher. Miss Harriet Livermc,c
from Massac achusetts She has been we'll educated,
and is of highly respectable family. After having
preached in Georgetown and in some of he church.
es IN this city. she, by the assistance Of the Penn.
sylvapIa deleg ,tion, obtained from Mr.. Speaker
Taylor the liberty to "give her testimony" she
calls her sermon, in Congress Hall. The novelty
attracted all the taste and fashion Of the city and
the room was filled and crowded At / O'Clock on
Sunday last she entered the Hall took the Speakers
chair, sang hymn. assisted by few of her friends,
prayed, and began her discourse. The text was
from Cd Sam. chap. xiii. and A." He that
ruIcth men. must be just, ruling in the fear OF
God. And he shall be as the lighi Of The morning
when the sun rseth, even morning without clouds !:
as the tender grass .pringine out of the earth by
clear shining after rain" Her exposition of this
beautiful text was not only bold, bu, felicilous and
eloquent. Her voice wa. clear her annuncation so
distinct as to be heard by all on the Hoor OF the
house. She drew fair and lovely character Of the
just ruler, and dwe long upon the good such an ons
may do in this as we'll as in other countries. The
sermon was more than an hour in length, and all
we're quiet and attentive. The President was there,
and at time, sat upon the steps which led to her
pulpit, the crowd being so great that for while It
was the most convenient place he could End. The
Secretary of War, and some Of the most dis.

Many recipes have been given to the public for
curing beef; most important item in he depart
ment oil domestic economy-we recommend the
following With great confidence, for TWO reasons -
First because we have been favored with it by a
lady who cannot be cxeeed lor good taste and good
management; and secondly because we have dined
on beet picked By this process. which was super
excellent. Nm. Farmer.


Recipe for curing Bert.


Prepare your brine in the middle OF October,
after the following msnner:-Cet thirty gallon
cask, take out one head, drive in the hung and put
some pitch on it TO prevent lesking see that the
cssk is quite tight and clean Put into il one pound
OF salt petre powdered, fifteen quarts Of salt, and
fifteen gallons OF cold water, stir it frequently until
dissolved, throw over the cssk thick cloth to keep
out the dust look al it Of aud TAXI off the
fifteen gallons oil cold water will exactly hold, in
solution. fifteen quarts oil good. clean Liverpool
SALT and pound Of salt pelre this brine will
be strong enough TO bear up an egg This hrino
will cure all the beef which private family
use in the OF the winter, and eqoies nothing
TO be done to it, t occasionally skimniing
he droas tina; rises; II must be kept In COOL dry
place.


For sailing your beef-get mclassss hogshead
and saw it in t@o. that The beef may have space to
lie on bore some holes IN the bottom Of the tubs,
and raise them side about inch, that the
bloody brine msy run off. Rub each piece Of your
beef very well with good Liverpool salt vast deal
depends upon rubbing the ssh into eyesy part i, is
unnecessary to put salt petre on il sprinkle good
deal Of salt on the bottom of the tub. When the
beef Is well sailed, lay it in the tub and be sure
you put the heshy side downward; put grea, deal
o. sal: ON your nsef alter it is packed in ina tub.
this protects il from animals You must lc, the
oeef lie in salt ten days. then take it out, brash Of
the sal, aud wipe i. with damp cloth put j, in the
ine with . bit oi board and weight to keep it
under. In about ten days it will uok red and be
Fl for The best time 10 sah beef is in the
latter end OF October if the weather be cool ard
f., m that time have it 10 succession. When your
beet is taken cu ol the tub, stir the salt about ia
dfv that il rsy he ready for the next p,eCes.--
Tongues are cured in &c same manner.

full articles.headline: MISS LIVERMORE.
full articles.article:
|


Our readers may have observed ia columns recent
y, notices Of Miss Lvermores intention preach at til,
Capitol and elsewhere Our engagements have allow
ed TO at end her preaching, had wished 10 do
Those Wit have heard her, speak highly OF her
gifts, and even enraptured by her eoqueuce
Among the later the esteemed Lady who is the autho
OF the following Letter, Of which have been allowed
take copy for publication 1t is addressed to The dagh
ter of the writer, who resides in distant part of the
try. Nat. Intel


Washington, 9th Jan, 1927.


My BELOVED CHILD:--l Witnessed scene
yesterday novel and impressive, that l cannot
torbear attempting description Of it. say at
! tempting. for the sensibies were more strongly
affected han the senses, consequently Just dein
cation is very difficult. IL had been rumored ior
some weeks, that woman OF considerable prctcn-
sons had solicited in vain for permission to preach
in the Representatives Hall The Capitol. So you
see, auci all the professions of veDeration for
sex, made by mankind, when tested by their acts
they say "Wha, good thing can come out of Naz-
sreth 70


Thanks to the Christian Pastors Of Georgetown
they invited h~r to their Churches, from whence
the tame OF her eloquence spread through the City
cur osity esaed over iberal prejudice, and
she was invited to preach al the Capitol. We at
tended at an early hour, and found the hall, lobby
and gallery, completely filled tina, it was almost
impossible to get admission: And | am told the



When looked ,ound and the numerous
audience, greater Than | had ever on any for
mer occasion, tiembled for the yet unseen female
VIII" was TO address them At length she appeared
attic nded by friend Her figure is good, her height
somewhat above mediutrity her lace pale, perhaps
some would say PLAIN but peasi' e, and inuc alive
% great serenity and goodness They were ho'h
dressed il a style simple and neat you would
have taken them Qu.kers. She ascended the
Az .e,b~ hn.t tar "a, nd h.
her. She commenced in The usual manner, by
=, aver and singing. She then read the ll2th psal
IN voice some shat huf,ieG AID trrmunus, and
elected her text tom Cd Samuel, 23d chap par,
o the Sd and all oi ;he 4 b VERSES" He that rul
.ih over rnrn must Just. ruling in the fear OF
God AM he shall bs The lleh, Of the MOI ming,
aheo the sun ristth even morning without clouds,
as t'e tende' grass sprnging out OF the earth BY
eirs, shining after rain


The President, and many members Of Con
sress weie es,n,. F,om her text you will read
IL, pc cei,e her address ended principally 70,
| the inlers oi the lation. Bot she embraced the
'hr ~h"lc multitude 1.-The iulers Of schools-the ru
iefs al 'amhes: and, as individuals, the rulers o
inf passirns.


Her language was correct, persuasive, and Iudg
,n.y by my own feelings. the profound attention snd
sympathy OF the audience. extremely eloquent
| Many weps even 10 sohbing e. FIRST yielded tc





| to he melting mood, ]. who thoushl my heart was
scared by sfnic,ion aud my eyes dried BY weeping
found that hestl r~Ienling, aud those eyes dssolvine
in tricklng ihsw


| Judging, as said. by my owo ferIngs, and have
no other test. | should say she is The most eloquent
p,eache' have listened to since the days Of Mr.
| WaddeH.


| But no language car do justice 10 the psthns OF
her singing For when she closed by singing
hymn, that might with pop'iely he termed pray
er, in which she asks the divine perlectons of eat h
sacred character recorded in Scripture. her vnice
wa. so melodious, aud her face beamed with such
heavenly goodness, as to resemble rau.hgu, alton
and you compelled to accord tnem ali TO her
| could have listened from morn ill noon and rrn
noon till dewy eve Of Summers day 1t ssvourec
more OF inspiration Than any thing ever witnessed
and to enoy the frame OF mind which think she
does. would ,elinqush the world. Call this rhsp
sody il you will bu, would to God YOU had besrs
her think you would have felt as did, and may
add, as now do"

A Real K,ntucLian.-A Kentuokian. we believe
of that class tamlisrly called a fog .Nerchant.
rode up to public house in the wes!. where's num-
he, OF gentlemen were seated in he piazza. Ahee
low bow to the company, h inquired It any pres
ent could infotm him what good tor ourn. A
young Physician (,hers being several present) step.
ned forward, and with much comp'slsance gave
him learned lecture on Burns, the mode ci treat
ment, &c. &c &c for which he was thanked politely
by the Ken'ut khan who informed him. that hi, pse-
scrpton would not answer hi, present complaint.
.. h,s saddle blanket had been very badly burnt the
nigh, previously. On hearing this the Physician
became exaspera,ed and told him il he would aligh,
he would give him Aogsiog. The Kentuckaa
-gain bowed and said that he would moi ahght Tor
TWO 1oggings let alone one, and rode off with muc.i
gravity and sell satisfaction.
